answer_html: Thus combining the two discussions shows us that either \(\displaystyle n = 23\) or \(\displaystyle n = 46\) completing the question.
answer_latex:
Thus combining the two discussions shows us that either
$\displaystyle n = 23$ or $\displaystyle n = 46$ completing the
question.
hints_html:
Recall that

\(\displaystyle \phi(n) = n\prod_{p \mid n}\left(1 - \frac{1}{p}\right)\)

Start with this and use divisibility rules to help.
hints_latex:
Recall that

$\displaystyle \phi(n) = n\prod_{p \mid n}\left(1 - \frac{1}{p}\right)$

Start with this and use divisibility rules to help.
hints_raw:
Recall that 

<math> \displaystyle \phi(n) = n\prod_{p \mid n}\left(1 - \frac{1}{p}\right)</math>

Start with this and use divisibility rules to help.
sols_html:
We begin by noting that

\(\displaystyle 2\cdot 11 = 22 = \phi(n) = n\prod_{p \mid n}\left(1 - \frac{1}{p}\right) = n\prod_{p \mid n}\frac{p-1}{p} = \prod_{p_{i}^{\alpha_{i}}\parallel n}p_{i}^{\alpha_{i}-1}(p-1)\)

where above we used the Fundamental Theorem of Arithmetic to write (recall that \(\displaystyle \parallel\) means fully divides)

\(\displaystyle n = \prod_{p_{i}^{\alpha_{i}}\parallel n} p_{i}^{\alpha_{i}}.\)

Our main equation of discussion will be

\(\displaystyle 2\cdot 11 = \prod_{p_{i}^{\alpha_{i}}\parallel n}p_{i}^{\alpha_{i}-1}(p_{i}-1)\).

We proceed in cases. First we discuss the powers of 2 in n.

. In this case, notice that 4 divides the right hand side of the main equation but only 2 divides the left hand side. This is a contradiction.

. In this case, notice that 2 divides the right hand side of the main equation and 2 divides the left hand side. However, if another odd prime divides n, then the right hand side is divisible by an extra power of 2 which is a contradiction. The remaining subcase in this case is if no odd primes divde n, that is, \(\displaystyle n = 4\). But since also \(\displaystyle \phi(4) = 2 \neq 22\) this case cannot occur.

”’Case 3

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle 2 \parallel n\end{aligned}\]

or n is odd”’. In either of these cases, since \(\displaystyle \phi\) is multiplicative and as \(\displaystyle \phi(2) = 1\), we have that either of these cases can occur, that is, if \(\displaystyle \phi(n) = 22\), then \(\displaystyle \phi(2n) = 22.\) Therefore, without loss of generality, we suppose 2 does not divide \(\displaystyle n\).

Now we deal with the odd primes. Notice that for each odd prime, we get a factor of 2 on the right hand side of the main equation. Thus only exactly one odd prime can occur. Thus \(\displaystyle n = p^{\alpha}\). Since only 2 and 11 occur as prime factors on the left hand side of the equation, we know that we must have that \(\displaystyle \alpha \leq 2\) (the right hand side of the main equation has an \(\displaystyle p^{\alpha-1}\) term so the factor could be 2). If \(\displaystyle \alpha =2\), then the prime p in question must be 11 since p divides the right hand side. So \(\displaystyle n = 11^{2}\) but this is inadmissable since \(\displaystyle \phi(11^{2}) \neq 22\). Thus n is a prime. For primes, we have that \(\displaystyle \phi(p) = p-1\). This value we know is 22 and so \(\displaystyle n = 23\).

Thus combining the two discussions shows us that either \(\displaystyle n = 23\) or \(\displaystyle n = 46\) completing the question.
sols_latex:
We begin by noting that

$\displaystyle 2\cdot 11 = 22 = \phi(n) = n\prod_{p \mid n}\left(1 - \frac{1}{p}\right) = n\prod_{p \mid n}\frac{p-1}{p} = \prod_{p_{i}^{\alpha_{i}}\parallel n}p_{i}^{\alpha_{i}-1}(p-1)$

where above we used the Fundamental Theorem of Arithmetic to write
(recall that $\displaystyle \parallel$ means \emph{fully divides})

$\displaystyle n = \prod_{p_{i}^{\alpha_{i}}\parallel n} p_{i}^{\alpha_{i}}.$

Our \emph{main equation} of discussion will be

$\displaystyle 2\cdot 11 = \prod_{p_{i}^{\alpha_{i}}\parallel n}p_{i}^{\alpha_{i}-1}(p_{i}-1)$.

We proceed in cases. First we discuss the powers of 2 in \emph{n}.

\textbf{Case 1\begin{align*}
\displaystyle 8 \mid n
\end{align*}}. In this case, notice that 4
divides the right hand side of the main equation but only 2 divides the
left hand side. This is a contradiction.

\textbf{Case 2\begin{align*}
\displaystyle 4 \parallel n
\end{align*}}. In this case, notice
that 2 divides the right hand side of the main equation and 2 divides
the left hand side. However, if another odd prime divides \emph{n}, then
the right hand side is divisible by an extra power of 2 which is a
contradiction. The remaining subcase in this case is if no odd primes
divde \emph{n}, that is, $\displaystyle n = 4$. But since also
$\displaystyle \phi(4) = 2 \neq 22$ this case cannot occur.

'''Case 3\begin{align*}
\displaystyle 2 \parallel n
\end{align*} or \emph{n} is odd'''. In
either of these cases, since $\displaystyle \phi$ is multiplicative and
as $\displaystyle \phi(2) = 1$, we have that either of these cases can
occur, that is, if $\displaystyle \phi(n) = 22$, then
$\displaystyle \phi(2n) = 22.$ Therefore, without loss of generality, we
suppose 2 does not divide $\displaystyle n$.

Now we deal with the odd primes. Notice that for each odd prime, we get
a factor of 2 on the right hand side of the main equation. Thus only
exactly one odd prime can occur. Thus $\displaystyle n = p^{\alpha}$.
Since only 2 and 11 occur as prime factors on the left hand side of the
equation, we know that we must have that $\displaystyle \alpha \leq 2$
(the right hand side of the main equation has an
$\displaystyle p^{\alpha-1}$ term so the factor could be 2). If
$\displaystyle \alpha =2$, then the prime \emph{p} in question must be
11 since \emph{p} divides the right hand side. So
$\displaystyle n = 11^{2}$ but this is inadmissable since
$\displaystyle \phi(11^{2}) \neq 22$. Thus \emph{n} is a prime. For
primes, we have that $\displaystyle \phi(p) = p-1$. This value we know
is 22 and so $\displaystyle n = 23$.

Thus combining the two discussions shows us that either
$\displaystyle n = 23$ or $\displaystyle n = 46$ completing the
question.
sols_raw:
We begin by noting that 

<math> \displaystyle 2\cdot 11 = 22 = \phi(n) = n\prod_{p \mid n}\left(1 - \frac{1}{p}\right) = n\prod_{p \mid n}\frac{p-1}{p} = \prod_{p_{i}^{\alpha_{i}}\parallel n}p_{i}^{\alpha_{i}-1}(p-1)</math>

where above we used the Fundamental Theorem of Arithmetic to write (recall that <math>\displaystyle \parallel </math> means ''fully divides'')

<math>
\displaystyle n = \prod_{p_{i}^{\alpha_{i}}\parallel n} p_{i}^{\alpha_{i}}.
</math>

Our ''main equation'' of discussion will be 

<math> \displaystyle 2\cdot 11 = \prod_{p_{i}^{\alpha_{i}}\parallel n}p_{i}^{\alpha_{i}-1}(p_{i}-1)</math>.

We proceed in cases. First we discuss the powers of 2 in ''n''.

'''Case 1: <math> \displaystyle 8 \mid n </math>'''. In this case, notice that 4 divides the right hand side of the main equation but only 2 divides the left hand side. This is a contradiction.

'''Case 2: <math> \displaystyle 4 \parallel n </math>'''. In this case, notice that 2 divides the right hand side of the main equation and 2 divides the left hand side. However, if another odd prime divides ''n'', then the right hand side is divisible by an extra power of 2 which is a contradiction. The remaining subcase in this case is if no odd primes divde ''n'', that is, <math> \displaystyle n = 4 </math>. But since also <math> \displaystyle \phi(4) = 2 \neq 22 </math> this case cannot occur.

'''Case 3: <math> \displaystyle 2 \parallel n </math> or ''n'' is odd '''. In either of these cases, since <math>\displaystyle \phi</math> is multiplicative and as <math> \displaystyle \phi(2) = 1</math>, we have that either of these cases can occur, that is, if <math>\displaystyle \phi(n) = 22</math>, then <math>\displaystyle \phi(2n) = 22.</math> Therefore, without loss of generality, we suppose 2 does not divide <math>\displaystyle n</math>. 

Now we deal with the odd primes. Notice that for each odd prime, we get a factor of 2 on the right hand side of the main equation. Thus only exactly one odd prime can occur. Thus <math> \displaystyle n = p^{\alpha} </math>. Since only 2 and 11 occur as prime factors on the left hand side of the equation, we know that we must have that <math> \displaystyle \alpha \leq 2 </math> (the right hand side of the main equation has an <math> \displaystyle p^{\alpha-1} </math> term so the factor could be 2).  If <math> \displaystyle \alpha =2 </math>, then the prime ''p'' in question must be 11 since ''p'' divides the right hand side. So <math> \displaystyle n = 11^{2} </math> but this is inadmissable since <math> \displaystyle \phi(11^{2}) \neq 22</math>. Thus ''n'' is a prime. For primes, we have that <math> \displaystyle \phi(p) = p-1 </math>. This value we know is 22 and so <math> \displaystyle n = 23 </math>. 

Thus combining the two discussions shows us that either <math> \displaystyle n = 23 </math> or <math> \displaystyle n = 46 </math> completing the question.
statement_html: Find all positive integers n such that \(\displaystyle \phi(n) = 22\) and prove that there are no others. Here \(\displaystyle \phi\) denotes the Euler \(\displaystyle \phi\) function.
statement_latex:
Find all positive integers \emph{n} such that
$\displaystyle \phi(n) = 22$ and prove that there are no others. Here
$\displaystyle \phi$ denotes the Euler $\displaystyle \phi$ function.
statement_raw: Find all positive integers ''n'' such that <math> \displaystyle \phi(n) = 22</math> and prove that there are no others. Here <math> \displaystyle \phi </math> denotes the Euler <math> \displaystyle \phi</math> function.
